objects.description: The malware sample, file, or other information is encoded.

objects.name: Demo Mode
objects.description: Inclusion of a demo binary/mode that is executed when token is absent or not privileged enough.

objects.name: Resolve TLD::DNS Communication
objects.description: Resolves top level domain.

objects.name: Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue
objects.description: Malware may generate advertising revenue by generating clicks of advertising links. The ATT&CK technique, [Generate Fraudulent Advertising Revenue](https://attack.mitre.org/techniques/T1472/), pertains only to mobile platform, but the behavior is applicable to other platforms as well.

objects.name: InternetWriteFile::WinINet
objects.description: Writes data to an open Internet file.

objects.name: Failed Network Connections
objects.description: Some emulated systems fail to handle some network communications; such failures will indicate the emulated environment.

objects.name: Zcash
objects.description: Access Zcash data.

objects.name: Synchronization
objects.description: Malware enables two or more processes/threads to share a resource.

objects.name: DDNS Domain Connect::DNS Communication
objects.description: Connects to dynamic DNS domain.

objects.name: IsDebuggerPresent
objects.description: The kernel32!IsDebuggerPresent API function call checks the PEB BeingDebugged flag to see if the calling process is being debugged. It returns 1 if the process is being debugged, 0 otherwise. This is one of the most common ways of debugger detection.

objects.name: Suicide Exit
objects.description: Malware terminates its execution based on a trigger condition or value (or because it has completed).

objects.name: Timing/Delay Check QueryPerformanceCounter
objects.description: Malware uses QueryPerformanceCounter in a timing/delay check.

objects.name: GET Request::HTTP Communication
objects.description: HTTP Get request.

objects.name: Confuser
objects.description: Uses Confuser packer.

objects.name: Pre-Debug
objects.description: Prevents debugger from attaching to process or to break until after the code of interest has been executed.

objects.name: Software Packing
objects.description: This code characteristic - Software Packing - can make static and behavioral analysis difficult and includes packing with software protectors, such as Themida and Armadillo [[1]](#1). Methods related to anti-analysis are below. This behavior covers both characteristics of the malware (i.e., how it is packed) as well as behaviors of the malware (e.g., the malware packs another executable file).

external_references.description: Jiang Ming et al, Towards Paving the Way for Large-Scale Windows Malware Analysis: Generic Binary Unpacking with Orders-of-Magnitude Performance Boost, October 2018,

objects.name: DNSChanger
objects.description: Used to change DNS settings to generate fraudulent advertising revenue.

objects.name: Dark Comet
objects.description: A Remote Access Trojan (RAT) that allows a user to control the system via a GUI. It has many features which allows a user to use it as administrative remote help tool; however, DarkComet has many features which can be used maliciously. DarkComet is commonly used to spy on the victims by taking screen captures, key-logging, or password stealing.

objects.name: Stuxnet
objects.description: A malicious worm targeting SCADA systems.

objects.name: TrickBot
objects.description: Trojan spyware program that has mainly been used for targeting banking sites. TrickBot is written in the C++ programming language.

objects.name: Geneio
objects.description: Geneio is a byproduct of the DYLD_PRINT_TIFILE vulnerability. Geneio can gain access to the MAC Keychain and persist until removed by the user.

objects.name: Rombertik
objects.description: This family of malware steals data the user enters into a browser and uses a variety of behaviors to hinder analysis.

objects.name: Ursnif
objects.description: A banking trojan that uses malware macros to evade sandbox detection. Variant of Gozi.

objects.name: Kraken
objects.description: A family of bots.

objects.name: CryptoLocker
objects.description: CryptoLocker is a family of ransomware.

objects.name: Poison-Ivy
objects.description: Remote Access Trojan (RAT).

objects.name: Conficker
objects.description: A worm targeting Microsoft Windows operations systems.

objects.name: MazarBot
objects.description: Targets Android phones via a poisoned text message.

objects.name: Locky Bart
objects.description: Locky Bart is ransomware.

objects.name: CryptoWall
objects.description: CryptoWall is a family of ransomware.

objects.name: UP007 Malware Family
objects.description: Description.

objects.name: Emotet
objects.description: Emotet is a banking trojan.

objects.name: SYNful Knock
objects.description: A modification of the router's firmware images used to maintain persistence.

objects.name: Hupigon
objects.description: A family of backdoors.

objects.name: WebCobra
objects.description: Cryptojacking malware.

objects.name: Gamut
objects.description: A spamming botnet.

objects.name: Heriplor
objects.description: This Trojan is associated with the Energetic Bear group  [[1]](#1).

objects.name: SamSam
objects.description: Ransomware.

objects.name: YiSpecter
objects.description: YiSpecter is Apple iOS malware that can download, install and launch arbitrary iOS apps, replace existing apps with those it downloads, hijack other apps’ execution to display advertisements, change Safari’s default search engine, bookmarks and opened pages, and upload device information to a C2 server. It uses tricks to hide its icons from iOS’s SpringBoard, which prevents the user from finding and deleting it. The components also use the same name and logos of system apps to trick iOS power users.

objects.name: Redhip
objects.description: An information stealer.

objects.name: Terminator
objects.description: A remote access tool (RAT).

objects.name: Mebromi
objects.description: A BIOS bootkit.

objects.name: BlackEnergy
objects.description: An HTTP-based botnet used mostly for DDoS attacks.

objects.name: Shamoon
objects.description: Data wiping malware.

objects.name: SearchAwesome
objects.description: Adware that intercepts encrypted web traffic to inject ads.

objects.name: GotBotKR
objects.description: Modified version of a publicly available backdoor name GoBot2. Modifications are mainly evasion techniques specific to South Korea.

objects.name: GravityRAT
objects.description: Evades detection by checking current CPU temperature.

objects.name: Bagle
objects.description: A mass-mailing computer worm affecting Microsoft Windows.

objects.name: Kovter
objects.description: A trojan that performs click-fraud.
An MBR bootkit and a BIOS bootkit targeting Award BIOS.
Modification of the router's firmware image that can be used to maintain persistence within a victim's network.
Uses API Hashing Method.
Sets "2019" as Windows' startup folder by modifying a registry value.
Intercepts data coming into and going out of device.
A 2018 variant includes a component that erases files and then wipes the master boot record, preventing file recovery.
Allows an attacker to control the system via a GUI.
Checks system temperature by recording thermal readings for detecting VMs. Heat levels indicate whether the system is a VM.
Intercepts encrypted web traffic to inject adds.
Learns about the system so it can drop compatible miner software.
After the Poison-Ivy server is running on the target machine, the attacker uses a Windows GUI client to control the target computer.
Code virtualization is added to the Locky Bart binary using WPProtect.
Injects miner code into a running process.
Some variants look for an unnamed mutex to ensure only one copy of itself is running on a system.
Performs click-fraud.
Encrypts files for ransom without any connection to the Internet.
Emotet macros are heavily obfuscated with junk functions and string substitutions.
Drops software that mines for cryptocurrency: Cryptonight or Claymore's Zcash miner, depending on system architecture.
Uses a domain name generator.
Alters DNS server settings to route to a rogue DNS server for the purpose of click hijacking.
Redhip detects VMWare, Virtual PC and Virtual Box. It also detects VM environments in general by considering timing lapses.

WebCobra injects malicious code to svchost.exe and uses an infinite loop to check all open windows and to compare each window’s title bar text with a set of strings to determine whether it is running in an isolated, malware analysis environment.
Launches distributed denial of service attacks that can target more than one IP address per hostname.
Can download and install arbitrary iOS apps.
Redhip samples are packed with different custom packers.

Stuxnet made the centrifuges at Iran's nuclear plant spin dangerously fast for 15 minutes, before returning to normal speed. About a month later, it slowed the centrifuges down for 50 minutes. This was repeated for several months, and over time the strain destroyed the machines.
Ursnif uses malware macros to evade sandbox detection.
Redhip detects all publicly available automated malware analysis workbenches (ThreatExpert, JoeBox, etc.).
A Trojan downloader.
Geneio installs the browser extension *~/Library/Safari/Extensions/Omnibar.safariextz*. It also creates the app files listed in the description above.

Gamut probes the infected system's SMTP port 25 by sending a test SMTP transaction to mail.ru and hotmail.com. If port 25 is open, the bot requests the spam template and email list, which it uses to send spam.
Uses a domain name generator.
Primary behavior is encrypting data.
Hupigon drops the file "Systen.dll" and adds the registry entry: HKEY_LOCAL_MACHINE\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\Notify\BITS DllName = "%System%\Systen.dll".
Conficker A has routine that causes the process to suicide exit if the keyboard language layout is set to Ukranian.
Dumping Kraken's c.dll module from the heap of its own process is tricky because its PE-header is wiped out.
From the command line, drops and unzips a password-protected Cabinet archive file.
Installs a backdoor.
Bagle uses its own SMTP engine to mass-mail itself as an attachment from an infected computer.
Redhip uses general approaches to detecting user level debuggers (e.g., Process Environment Block 'Being Debugged' field), as well as specific checks for kernel level debuggers like SOFICE.
Injects secondary payload into memory.
Executes differently depending on whether it's running on an x86 or x64 system.
SamSam is ransomware.
Stores malware files in the Registry instead of the hard drive.
The Terminator rat evades a sandbox by not executing until after a reboot. Most sandboxes don't reboot during an analysis.
Primary behavior is encrypting data.
Redhip uses general approaches to detecting user level debuggers (e.g., Process Environment Block 'Being Debugged' field), as well as specific checks for kernel level debuggers like SOFICE.
Downloads and executes Claymore's Zcash miner from a remote server.
GotBotKR reinstalls its running instance if it is removed.

objects.name: MBC
objects.description: The Malware Behavior Catalog (MBC) is a catalog of malware objectives and behaviors, created to support malware analysis-oriented use cases, such as labeling, similarity analysis, and standardized reporting.

objects.name: File Manipulation Micro-objectives
objects.description: Micro-behaviors related to file manipulation.

objects.name: Lateral Movement
objects.description: Behaviors that enable propagation through a compromised system or infected files. The malware may move actively (e.g., gain access to a machine directly) or passively (e.g., send malicious email).

objects.name: Anti-Static Analysis
objects.description:
Behaviors and code characteristics that prevent static analysis or make it more difficult. Simple static analysis identifies features such as embedded strings, header information, hash values, and file metadata (e.g., creation date). More involved static analysis involves the disassembly of the binary code.

Two primary resources for anti-static analysis behaviors are [[1]](#1) and [[2]](#2).

external_references.description: Unprotect Project, a database about malware self-defense and protection.
InDepthUnpacking, course content for teaching malware anti-analysis techniques and mitigations, with emphasis on packers.

objects.name: Communication Micro-objectives
objects.description: Micro-behaviors that enable malware to communicate.

objects.name: Impact
objects.description: Behaviors that enable malware to achieve its mission of manipulating, interrupting, or destroying systems and/or data.

objects.name: Data Manipulation Micro-objectives
objects.description: Micro-behaviors related to malware manipulating data.

objects.name: Credential Access
objects.description: Behaviors to obtain credential access, allowing it or its underlying threat actor to assume control of an account, with the associated system and network permissions.

objects.name: Hardware Micro-objectives
objects.description: Micro-behaviors related to hardware.

objects.name: Command and Control
objects.description: Behaviors malware may use to communicate with systems under its control within a target network. There are many ways malware can establish command and control with various levels of covertness, depending on system configuration and network topology. Behaviors may relate to C2 servers or a bot that is part of a botnet.

objects.name: Collection
objects.description: Behaviors that identify and gather information, such as sensitive files, from a target network prior to exfiltration. This objective includes locations on a system or network where the malware may look for information to exfiltrate.

objects.name: Exfiltration
objects.description: Behaviors that steal data from the system on which it executes. This includes stored data (e.g., files) as well as data input into applications (e.g., web browser).

objects.name: Defense Evasion
objects.description: Behaviors that evade detection or avoid other defenses.

objects.name: Discovery
objects.description: Behaviors that aim to gain knowledge about the system and internal network.

objects.name: Persistence
objects.description: Malware aims to remain on a system regardless of system events.

objects.name: Privilege Escalation
objects.description: Behaviors that aim to obtain a higher level of permission.

objects.name: Cryptography Micro-objectives
objects.description: Micro-behaviors that enable malware to use crypto.

objects.name: Process Micro-objectives
objects.description: Micro-behaviors related to processes.

objects.name: Memory Manipulation Micro-objectives
objects.description: Micro-behaviors related to malware manipulating machine memory.

objects.name: Anti-Behavioral Analysis
objects.description:
Behaviors that prevent, obstruct, or evade behavioral analysis (sandbox, debugger, etc). Because the underlying methods differ, separate "detection" and "evasion" behaviors are defined for some anti-behavioral analysis areas (e.g., anti-debugger). 

Two primary resources for anti-behavioral analysis behaviors are [[1]](#1) and [[2]](#2).

external_references.description: Unprotect Project, a database about malware self-defense and protection.
InDepthUnpacking, course content for teaching malware anti-analysis techniques and mitigations, with emphasis on packers.

objects.name: Execution
objects.description: Behaviors that execute code on a system to achieve a variety of goals.
